title: ELEXIS travel grants

author: Bolette Sandford Pedersen, Centre for Language Technology, University of Copenhagen

segmentation: I believe they sent for Peterson from the University of Copenhagen and we are leading the initiative in Alexis called Transnational Access, which is realized through travel grants.

So the idea with the travel grants is that you can actually physically go and visit mylius lexicographical infrastructures that are in Alexis and in exchange knowledge and gain knowledge to your own project.

So the idea is that you get your travel covered and actually also I'm sure that you will get the lexicographical expertise or the IT expertise at the host infrastructure to guide you through and help you during your visit.
So these are the countries where we have infrastructures that can be visited in cloud and elexis and on the website you will see them all listed.
So it could be Slovenia, the Netherlands, Austria, Serbia, Bulgaria, Hungary is wrong Denmark, Germany, Estonia or Spain.
And if you click on each infrastructure, you will get in depth information regarding what kinds of lexicographical resources are being done at the particular infrastructures.
Which kind of tools are they using?
And so forth.
So you will be able to get an impression of whether it could be.
For you to go there.
So for instance, I've clicked here on the Hungarian Academy of Sciences and you can see which dictionaries they're making, which tools they're using, and so forth.
Likewise, here with the denser sporleder to escape in Copenhagen, you'll see which tools are they using, which resource are they developing?
So how many grants are available?
Well, we have four or five calls All in all, and we've just finished the second call, so there are three more calls to go.
It regards travels of the duration of one to three weeks.
And All in all, a number of 30 to 40 grants will be available during the project's lifetime, and we generally have a summer call and a winter call.
So the next call, which is the summer call, will be launched in June 2019 and a deadline around the beginning of August.

And we reimbursed travel accommodation and per diem for for the travelers and the application of the grand holders is of course to perform the visit, but also to make a report after the visit of the outcomes that will be in some form publicly available from our website.
And who can apply?
Well, researchers or lexicographers within the EU Member States or associated countries?

And we do recommend that if you're interested in applying that you contact the host in infrastructure, so sort of the calibrate expectations so that you are sure that you can actually get out of get the outcome that you're expecting from your visit, and then you should make a project application including a project Anna Time plan, good arguments of why the particular infrastructure would be helpful to your project, and a budget estimate.

And the the applications are reviewed by the Election Selection Committee and within a month or so we we provide notification to the applicants of whether they have been granted it not or not, and the success rate has been quite high for the tool.
First rounds.
So 50% of the applications have been granted, so it's quite good chance to get the grant if you apply.

And I hope you had the opportunity yesterday actually to to go to the poster session and and meet some of the current grand holders and some of the people who have actually already done their visits and presented their outcomes and they will be.
The website will be updated with these sort of stories and reports and you can already see three or four of them on the website and get inspired to how what kind of project or visit you could.
Soul.
So I guess that was it.
No, yeah.
